title: What are the different theories and discoveries in the history of animal magnetism and how were they perceived?
first_phrase: In this text, Dr. Énrico Morselli, a professor at the Medical Faculty of Turin, discusses the history of animal magnetism and its evolution into modern-day magnetism. He traces the discovery and development of various aspects of magnetism including somnambulism, suggestion vocal, and the subtlety of perception. However, these developments were often overtaken by absurd theories like electro-biology and force odique that obscured the true nature of magnetism. Donato was the first to apply new methods to magnetize healthy individuals methodically. The text goes on to discuss the misconceptions and superstitions surrounding magnetism, the absurd theories of fluid vital, force de volonté, electrodynamisme, etc.
content: Viennent ensuite les superstitions bizarres du spiritisme de Cahagnet et d’Allan-Kardec, des tables tournantes, des médiums, que quelques-uns s’obstinent â mêler et confondre avec le magnétisme animal, quand c’est une chose tout à fait différente, ét cachant peut-être aussi quelque autrè phénomène physio-psychologique obscur et ignoré. Viennent enfin les théories secondaires, dans lesquelles se divise la doctrine primitive du fluide rnesmérfeii, c’est-à-dire les hypothèses toutes absurdes du fluide vital, de Noizet (1820) ; de la force de volonté de Grimes et du peuple qui se transmet du magnétiseur au magnétisé ; de Y électrodynamisme de Durand, de Gros (1855) et les dernières de la force nerveuse transmissible selon Rambosson (1879), du nevrisme-irradiant, selon Baréty (1881), de l’ondulation èthérèè de Perronet (1884) et tant d’autres semblables. Dr Énrico Morselli. Professeur k la Faculté de médecine de Turin. (à continuer.) Je me suis plaint, pago 119, d’un des nombreux emprunts qui ine sont continuellement faits par des écrivains qui trouvent plus commode de copier que de penser et plu profitable de plagier qüe de citer leurs auteurs.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the history of mesmerism and spiritualism is complex and often intertwined with other pseudoscientific beliefs such as table-turning and mediumship. While many secondary theories have been proposed over the centuries, it's important to remember that these ideas lack credible evidence and have been largely discredited by modern scientific understanding. As we move forward, we must continue to approach these topics with a critical eye and a dedication to evidence-based research.
